did.unittitle: Science in American Life exhibition records

bioghist.p: In 1991, the American Chemical Society agreed to consult on and contribute funds to an exhibit entitled Science in American Life (SAL) at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History (NMAH). The exhibit opened in 1994 and remained on view until 2006. The NMAH had control over the exhibit's content, and in the end, the ACS felt that the portrayal of chemistry was very negative. Ned D. Heindel (b. 1937) is a professor of Chemistry at Lehigh University. He was President of the American Chemical Society (ACS) in 1994, and from 1985 to 1996 was a Director of the ACS. In this latter role, he collected materials about the SAL exhibit's development and about the fallout that resulted from the differing views on the presentation of chemistry in the exhibit.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of documents relating to the Science in American Life exhibit. Materials include: the Smithsonian's initial feasibility study for the exhibit; draft scripts of the exhibit; public relations plans; a copy of a study conducted by the Smithsonian on visitors' responses to the exhibit; correspondence files from the director and one of the members of the ACS advisory committee; publicity materials and other documents on the Hand-On Science Center; and sample activity books. The collection also includes a comprehensive "briefing book" on ACS's response to the exhibit assembled by Heindel, which includes minutes from meetings of the advisory committee, press coverage of the exhibit, a copy of the advisory agreement between the ACS and the Smithsonian.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
